prompt: Is it mandatory to pay taxes in France?

options.text: Yes. Every resident has the legal duty to contribute to public expenses by paying taxes according to income
Only civil servants must do so
No, each person pays if they wish
No, only businesses and foreigners pay taxes

explanation: Yes, paying taxes is a legal obligation for all (individuals and companies) with taxable income in France. It is a civic duty: these financial contributions fund public services (schools, hospitals, infrastructure, etc.) and the State. Refusing to pay taxes can lead to penalties and prosecution.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: What is Defense and Citizenship Day (JDC) for young French people?

options.text: An information session on civics and the military that all French citizens must complete around age 16-18, replacing military service
A national demonstration in support of the army

explanation: The JDC is a Defense and Citizenship Day that all young French people (boys and girls) must attend, usually at age 17. Set up after conscription was suspended, this day—run by the Ministry of the Armed Forces—explains national defense and reminds participants of citizens' rights and duties. A JDC certificate is issued and required for certain exams or competitions. (It replaced the JAPD in 2011.)
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Is refusing to hire someone because of their religion, sex or origin allowed by law?

options.text: Yes, an employer is free to choose
No, it is illegal discrimination punishable by law
It depends on the religious reason

explanation: No. Refusing to hire someone for reasons such as religion, sex, ethnic origin, sexual orientation, health status, etc., is unlawful discrimination. The Labor Code strictly prohibits discrimination in hiring. Only skills and professional experience should guide recruitment. Proven discrimination exposes the employer to civil and criminal penalties (up to 3 years in prison and a 45,000 euro fine).
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Do women have the right to vote and be elected in France on the same basis as men?

options.text: Yes, since 1944 women have the same political rights as men (vote and eligibility)
No, they can only vote but not be elected
No, they obtained the vote but not before 1993
Yes, except for the office of President

explanation: Yes. Since the ordinance of April 21, 1944, French women are voters and eligible on the same terms as men. French women first voted in 1945. Today the Constitution affirms equality of political rights; laws even encourage gender parity in candidate lists. (The first women deputies were elected in 1945. A woman may of course be President if elected.)
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Is marriage between people of the same sex allowed by law in France?

options.text: Yes, since the 2013 "Marriage for All" law, two people of the same sex may marry
Yes, but only as a civil union (PACS)
No, unless they raise children together

explanation: Yes. Since the law of May 17, 2013 (Marriage for All), civil marriage is open to same-sex couples in France. Same-sex spouses have the same rights and duties as any married couple (including adoption). Previously, same-sex couples could only enter a PACS; now they may choose to be pacsed or married.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Is polygamy (having several spouses at the same time) allowed in France?

options.text: No, it is forbidden by the Civil Code
It depends on the country of origin

explanation: No, polygamy is illegal in France. The Civil Code allows only one simultaneous union: one cannot be married to more than one person. Bigamy/polygamy is a criminal offense. Also, if a polygamous foreigner acquires French nationality, they must renounce polygamy (only one spouse may come through family reunification). Equality between spouses and monogamy are firmly established.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Are female genital mutilations (excision) allowed in France?

options.text: Yes, if it is a cultural tradition
No, they are criminally punished acts of violence
Only with the consent of an adult

explanation: No, excision and any sexual mutilation are absolutely forbidden and treated as very serious violence. Practicing or allowing excision on a minor is a crime punishable by heavy sentences (up to 20 years in prison). Even if customary in some countries, French law protects girls' bodily integrity and severely punishes these acts, seen as human rights violations.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: From what age may a young person work full time in France (outside supervised apprenticeships)?
explanation: 16 is the minimum legal age to work full time in France. Schooling is compulsory until 16, and before that age employing a child is forbidden (except tightly controlled exceptions like artistic work or apprenticeship from 15 under school status). From 16, a young person may sign a work contract, but until 18 some dangerous activities remain banned and occupational health monitors fitness.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: What does the acronym SMIC mean in the French labor context?

options.text: The Minimum Interprofessional Growth Wage, i.e., the legal minimum wage in France

explanation: SMIC stands for Salaire Minimum Interprofessionnel de Croissance. It is the legal minimum hourly wage in France; no employee may be paid less (for full time it is roughly 1,747 euros gross in 2025). The SMIC is adjusted regularly based on inflation and growth.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: What is the legal weekly working time in France (for full-time work)?
explanation: 35 hours per week is the legal working time for full-time employment in France. Beyond that, hours are counted as overtime. This 35-hour limit was introduced by the Aubry laws (1998-2002) to promote jobs. Many employees work more via overtime, but 35 hours remains the legal reference (averaged weekly or yearly by agreement).
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Does an employee have the right to join a union of their choice to defend their interests?

options.text: Yes, freedom of association is guaranteed: anyone may join or create a union freely
Yes, but only in large companies
No, unions are banned in the public sector

explanation: Yes, union freedom is a fundamental right (in the 1946 preamble and the Labor Code). Any employee (public or private) may freely join the union of their choice, or create one, without employer interference. Union discrimination (punishing or refusing to hire because of union activity) is illegal. Unions play a key role representing employees.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Do French employees have the right to strike (stop work to press demands)?

options.text: Yes, the right to strike has been recognized by the Constitution since 1946
Yes, but only with employer authorization

explanation: Yes, the right to strike is a constitutional right in France. Any employee may strike to support professional demands, respecting certain rules (notice in public services, collective not personal action, etc.). This right, in the 1946 Preamble, is a major social gain. There are limits for some professions (police cannot strike) or to ensure minimum service (transport, hospitals), but generally it is a fundamental liberty.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: What is the “presumption of innocence” in French law?

options.text: The idea that an accused is probably guilty
The principle that anyone accused is considered innocent until legal proof of guilt
A mere phrase with no legal effect
A privilege reserved for public figures

explanation: The presumption of innocence means anyone prosecuted is considered innocent until a final judgment establishes guilt. Enshrined in the 1789 Declaration and the Code of Criminal Procedure, it is essential: the burden of proof is on the prosecution, and doubt must benefit the accused. In practice it entails the right to a fair trial, and not being publicly presented as guilty before judgment, etc.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: At what age does one reach legal adulthood in France?
explanation: 18. Since 1974, civil majority is 18. At that age one is legally an adult: full civil capacity (sign contracts, marry without parental consent, etc.) and political capacity (vote). Before 1974, majority was 21. At 18 other rights/responsibilities also apply (e.g., census, JDC, etc.).
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Does the death penalty still exist in France?

options.text: Yes, but it is no longer applied

explanation: No, the death penalty has been abolished since the law of October 9, 1981 (presented by Robert Badinter). France thus joined abolitionist nations. Since then no death sentence can be passed or carried out. This abolition is now in the Constitution (1946 Preamble) and France advocates globally for universal abolition.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Under what conditions may the State expropriate an owner of property (take it against their will)?

options.text: Only if public use justifies it and with fair prior compensation paid to the owner
At the request of a majority of neighbors
By simple decision of the mayor, without cause

explanation: Property is guaranteed, but Article 17 of the 1789 Declaration provides expropriation only for public necessity and with just and prior compensation. The State or local authorities can, for example, expropriate land to build a road or hospital deemed of public interest, but it must be declared of public utility and the owner must be compensated at value. Any abusive expropriation without compensation would be unconstitutional.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: May a pregnant woman be fired by her employer because of her pregnancy?

options.text: Yes, if her condition disrupts the company
No, dismissing a woman because she is pregnant is illegal
Yes, but only during maternity leave
No, except in the first three months of pregnancy

explanation: No, it is strictly forbidden to dismiss a woman because she is pregnant. The law protects pregnant women: from the start of pregnancy and during maternity leave (and even 10 weeks after), an employer may dismiss them only for gross misconduct unrelated to pregnancy or serious economic reasons. Pregnancy must not lead to sanction or discrimination. Any dismissal due to pregnancy is void and exposes the employer to penalties.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Is moral or sexual harassment at work punished by French law?

options.text: Yes, these are offenses under the Labor Code and Penal Code
Moral harassment is not legally defined
It is not serious; it is tolerated in the private sector
It is only an internal company matter, not for courts

explanation: Yes, moral and sexual harassment are strictly forbidden and punished by law. The Labor Code and Penal Code define them precisely. Moral harassment (repeated acts degrading working conditions) and sexual harassment (repeated sexual remarks or conduct violating dignity or creating a hostile environment) are offenses. The perpetrator risks up to 2 years in prison (3 with aggravating factors) and fines. Companies must prevent and sanction such acts, and victims may press charges.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Do all French citizens have the right to the same pay for equal work, whether male or female?

options.text: Yes, but it is not written in law
Yes, the "equal pay for equal work" principle is in law: a woman must be paid like a man for the same job
No, it depends on individual negotiations
No, women's pay may be lower depending on agreements

explanation: Yes, pay equality between women and men has been a legal obligation since 1972. The Labor Code imposes "equal pay for equal work": no pay difference may be based on sex. Despite persistent gaps in practice (part-time, job types, etc.), legally a woman in the same job with the same experience and qualification must receive the same pay as a man. Employers can be sanctioned for unjustified pay gaps.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Do foreign asylum beneficiaries (refugees) in France have the same fundamental rights as French citizens?

options.text: Yes. A recognized refugee has protection and the same fundamental rights (housing, work, health, etc.) as any legal resident
No, they live in camps without rights
They have protection but cannot work or get health care

explanation: Yes. The right of asylum is a constitutional principle in France: anyone persecuted may be protected and, once recognized as a refugee by OFPRA, gets a residence permit and the same social rights as any resident (work, education, social aid, health, etc.). Refugees must obey French laws like everyone else, but are protected from return to their country of origin and enjoy full legal integration.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: What is the legal voting age in France?
explanation: 18 years old. In France, voting rights are acquired at the age of majority, set at 18.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Which document allows a French citizen to prove identity abroad?
explanation: The passport. The passport is the official document for traveling and proving identity abroad.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: What is a "jury populaire" in France?

options.text: Citizens drawn by lot for a trial in a cour d'assises

explanation: Citizens drawn by lot for a trial in a cour d'assises. They participate in court decisions for the most serious criminal cases.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: What is the main role of the Defender of Rights?

options.text: Fight discrimination and defend citizens' rights

explanation: Fight discrimination and defend citizens' rights. It is an independent authority created in 2011.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: In France, what happens if you do not pay your taxes?
explanation: Financial penalties and prosecution. Paying taxes is a constitutional duty.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Is child labor allowed in France?

options.text: Yes from age 14 with an exemption

explanation: Yes from age 14 with an exemption. It is strictly regulated and requires parental and administrative authorization.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Which foundational text guarantees fundamental freedoms in France?

options.text: The Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen

explanation: The Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen. It dates from 1789 and is still cited in the Constitution.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: What is the legal weekly working time in France (Dec. 2025)?
explanation: 35 hours. This is the legal weekly duration for a full-time job.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: What is the carte Vitale for?

options.text: To receive reimbursement of health care costs

explanation: To receive reimbursement of health care costs. It is tied to national health insurance.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: May a French citizen freely criticize the government?

options.text: Yes, within the limits of the law
No, unless a judge authorizes it

explanation: Yes, within the limits of the law. Freedom of expression is a right, but must respect laws (defamation, hate speech, etc.).
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Is the tax return mandatory in France?
explanation: Yes, for every adult taxpayer. Even if no tax is due, the annual return remains compulsory.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Is the French judiciary independent of political power?

options.text: No, it is directed by the president
Yes, it is a fundamental principle of the Republic
No, it depends on the government

explanation: Yes, it is a fundamental republican principle. The judiciary is separate from the executive and legislative branches.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: What is the mission of public school in France?

options.text: Educate, teach and ensure equality of opportunity

explanation: Educate, teach and ensure equality of opportunity. Public school has a republican mission of training and empowerment.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Is military service mandatory in France?

options.text: No, but a Defense and Citizenship Day is mandatory

explanation: No, but a Defense and Citizenship Day is mandatory. It informs about rights and duties related to defense.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Who may run as a candidate in a municipal election?

options.text: Any adult French citizen registered to vote

explanation: Any adult French citizen registered to vote.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Which authority can sanction a citizen who commits a criminal offense?
explanation: A judge. Only the judiciary can judge and sanction an offense.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Are blank votes counted in official results?

options.text: No, they are not counted among valid votes
Yes, they automatically elect the second candidate

explanation: No, they are not counted among valid votes. They are distinguished from null votes but do not affect the final result.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Can you refuse an identity check requested by the police?

options.text: No, except if you are a minor

explanation: No, it is an offense. Refusal can be penalized if the check is justified.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: Which freedom allows citizens to demonstrate in the streets?
explanation: Freedom of expression. The right to demonstrate is a form of expression protected by law, subject to notification.
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen

prompt: May you publish anything on the internet?

options.text: Yes, it is a free space
No, the law applies online too
Yes, if it is on a private network

explanation: No, the law also applies online. The internet does not exempt anyone from rules (defamation, hate speech, fake news, etc.).
category: Rights and Duties of the Citizen
